config.question: How did the rise of short-staple cotton strengthen the hold of slavery and the plantation on the southern economy?

choices.content: It could grow anywhere in the South, which gave rise to more plantations and therefore slaves.
Clothes made from short-staple cotton were of better quality and were in high demand.
Short-staple cotton was immune to diseases and hence was preferred by most cotton growers.
Short-staple cotton was labor-intensive, and therefore more slaves were required.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Short-staple cotton only really took off when the cotton gin made cleaning the cotton feasible on a large scale. This type of cotton had more seeds, which made it necessary to invent the cotton gin to remove these seeds. See L.O. 11.3 How was slavery related to economic success in the South?
